ABSTRACT

Proposal Number: 0644789
Principal Investigator: Kretzschmar, Ilona
Affiliation: CUNY City College
Proposal Title: CAREER: Uniquely functionalized nanoparticles for hierarchical self-assembly of three-dimensional structures


Intellectual Merit:
The synthesis of T-structures proposed in this work could serve as an interesting model system for a plasmonic switch. The site-specific modification of particle surfaces, i.e., patch particles, and subsequent molecularly directed assembly advance the area of self-assembly by providing guidelines for the choice of binding energies, particle concentrations, and patch sizes. The T-structure assembly serves as a model system for achieving branched structures containing the elements crucial for three-dimensional assembly. Further, the patchy particles may also serve as surfactants, sensors, and particle probes for the advancement of the understanding of colloidal suspensions and emulsion stabilization.

Broader Impact:
CCNY is a recognized minority-serving institution, which serves a diverse undergraduate student body of Hispanic (36%), African American (30%), Asian (23%), and White (21%) students. The students will profit from the active research in the area of molecularly directed particle assembly. The organization of an IREU program provides CCNY undergraduates with exposure to research at an international level. Further, the individual mentoring proposed will provide female and minority students with a mentoring network early on in their careers. Collaboration with the Louis-Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (LSAMP) will channel students from underrepresented groups into the program. The exposure of future journalists, writers, and producers to nanotechnology is likely to have a strong impact on our media-oriented society and will help to increase the awareness of non-technical writers to the potential applications of nanotechnology and the effect of public opinion on the development of the area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research and Educational Goals of this CAREER award were to develop guidelines for the directed, three-dimensional (3D) assembly of patchy particles, i.e., particles coated with specific areas of various materials   and the development of educational programs that would increase the participation and competitiveness of students from underrepresented groups as well as introduce nanotechnology at the City College of New York (CCNY) and the City University of New York (CUNY).

For the accomplishment of these two goals, seven objectives were identified: (1) Identification and testing of linker molecules and particle-particle interactions that enable patch-specific interaction for directed assembly, (2) preparation of patchy particles with one, two, and three orthogonal patches, (3) Directed assemble of these particles into structures, (4) use of computation to predict assembly and develop design rules for 3D assembly, (5) increase diversity and number of students from underrepresented groups in STEM disciplines through year-round mentoring, (6) create an international research exchange program for students between CCNY, USA, and the Royal Institute of Technology (KTH) in Stockholm, Sweden, (7) develop nanonuggets and nanomaterials courses for CUNY.

Research Outcomes:

Our research has identified magnetic and electric interactions as suitable interactions for the directed assembly of patchy particles. For example, we have been able to pre-program the assembly   of patchy particles with one gold patch that covers 11, 25, and 50% of the surface or two patches of 25% that cover the particles on two poles. These patchy particles are prepared via two techniques; one involves the glancing angle deposition (GLAD) method and the other uses an additional template (template-assisted GLAD). In the GLAD method, particles are assembled in a one-particle thick layer such that each particle is surrounded by six others followed by deposition of a metal vapor. Depending on the angle between substrate and deposition source only portions of the particle surface are covered leading to particles with patches ranging from 4 – 50%. One limitation of this technique is the patch shape dependence on the six surrounding particles. As a result, the template-assisted GLAD technique was developed, which uses the assembly of particles into parallel grooves on a planar surface to align all particles in the same way with the source leading to patches of identical size and shape and allowing the variation of the patch shape from symmetric to asymmetric. Dimers and particle chains have been assembled using molecular linkers and magnetic/electric fields . One application of these chains is their use as an in situ microviscometer. In order to predict and understand particle behavior during assembly, we have employed dynamic density functional methods and molecular dynamics simulation techniques .

Educational Outcomes:

Support of this project has led to the implementation of a year-round mentoring program for CCNY undergraduate students. Students meet with the PI on a weekly basis to discuss academic progress, career plans, graduate school applications and research opportunities. Overall, this mentoring program has affected more than 50 students of whom ~50% have moved on into MS and PhD programs. It has also changed the awareness of undergraduate students with respect to quality of mentoring, accessibility of resources, and professional training. High school students (6) were also regularly involved in the research endeavor many of them returning for a second summer internship.
